data.title: Frame vs Element Actions
data.description: What's the difference between Frame and Element Actions?
data.body:
These two are different, and serve different purposes. 

Frame actions come in handy when you want something to happen at a certain point in time. For example, you want to stop the animation when it reaches frame 50. 

Element actions are good when you want something to happen when the user interacts with that element. For example, you want the animation to stop when the user clicks on a button. 

So, in short, they don't influence each other, they are two different features, which of course can be combined. For example: You want the animation to stop at frame 50 (frame action) and resume when the user clicks on your button (element action).

Learn more here: https://www.haiku.ai/blog/understanding-actions/

data.title: Removing the username from the method name and meta data
data.description: The embedded JS contains the name of account. Is there a way to avoid this?
data.body:
If you're using our CDN to host the files (e.g. the Codepen that Animator sets up for you), this metadata is required. 

If you're hosting the code yourself, you can use a javascript minifier OR manually edit the variable name & invocation using find + replace. You can download the file from the CDN and make these changes, then host on whatever server you'd like.

data.title: Renaming a project
data.description: Can I change the name of my project?
data.body: The easiest way is to duplicate your project in the dashboard and give the new project a new name.

data.title: Animating z-Index
data.description: Mid animation I need a layer to move to the front and back.
data.body:
For this particular use case we recommend animating the z-index property rather than position-z .

You can find z-index by expanding the "Style" property of any element.


You can also find other style properties by clicking the [+ Add] next to any element's name, or you can always apply these manually through the code in the code tab.

data.title: Using Placeholders
data.description: How to nest components in a codebase
data.body:
By marking an element as a placeholder, you will be able to specify the actual content of that placeholder in the codebase. The content to specify can be anything — text, images, React components, etc.  A placeholder can be created out of any element on the stage, including a text box or a rectangle.

You can turn any element on stage into a placeholder by selecting it, choosing the [+ Add] button in the Properties Panel, and selecting Control Flow > Placeholder.

Then set a value for the placeholder: either a numeric index or a selector. For example, enter 0 as the value. This means that the zero-th index child element passed into your animation component will be rendered in the place of your placeholder 0.  

For example:

<MyAnimatorComponent><div>Some content</div></MyAnimatorComponent>

Just count up from 0 for the next placeholder if you want more than one.

Tip: You can add a React or Angular child to your Animator component.  If that child matches the selector, it will be swapped in at runtime.  If you chose a numeric index instead of a selector, the nth child of that component will match the index n. 

This would allow you to do something like:

<div>
  <YourHaikuComponent>
    <div id="my-id">Any React content here {this.someData}</div>
  </YourHaikuComponent>
</div>


Where that div with "Any React content here" would be subbed into a controlFlow.placeholder="#my-id" OR a controlFlow.placeholder=0 


Note: Currently we support placeholders for React, Angular, and Vue, but not yet for Vanilla JS.

data.title: File size
data.description: Why are my animation folders large?
data.body:
Animator is versioning your design files in Git. 

In the current implementation, every time you make a design change in Sketch an entire copy of the Sketch file is maintained, enabling you to go back in time to any revision of that file. 

The problem here is the disk usage, of course — every change stacks up, especially with large design files. 

We have plans to automatically offer 'LFS', which is an extension to Git that manages large files much more efficiently. 

If this is causing pressing pain in the meantime, there's a way to remove the sketch files from your projects' histories, but it would require some command-line work. Essentially, follow this process here: https://help.github.com/articles/removing-sensitive-data-from-a-repository/#using-filter-branch to target your individual .sketch (or .ai) files, and then run git gc

data.title: Understanding the files
data.description: Why is there a separate `HaikuCore...min.js` and `index.embed.js`?
data.body:
The idea of index.embed.js  is to allow you to host multiple animations without needing to load multiple copies of Core on the same page. It’s a much smaller file, suited to some sorts of use cases (e.g. legacy web apps that don’t use modern build tooling) and less likely to crop up in a brand new app built off today-standard JS framework. 

We also provide index.standalone.js —which bundles a copy of Core along with the animation for a situation where you need to put exactly one animation on a page for some reason. 

We don’t expect these to be common use cases, but they’re supported.

data.title: Assets supplied by the CDN
data.description: Are there any assets not supplied by the CDN?
data.body: Everything except for design assets (e.g. Sketch files) are available on the CDN.

data.title: Error in production website
data.description: Uncaught TypeError: timeline.matchesCriteria is not a function
data.body:
If you run into this error please check the version of @haiku/core you are using via Object.keys(window.HaikuCore) in the console.

If it shows you something like this ["3.2.19", "3.4.6"]  it means that you have multiple versions of Animator getting compiled in.

If you’re using yarn or npm it should resolve the latest version, meaning the package.json for the @haiku/ modules should be using versions such as  "^3.2.19" and "^3.4.6" .

A way to solve this issue is to use "resolutions" in the package.json of your project. For example:

This should work with both npm and yarn, ensuring you don’t pick up the extra version of @haiku/core in your bundle.

data.title: Glossary
data.description: How are the different pieces of Animator called?
data.body:
In this article we'll cover the different pieces that make up Animator, what they are for and their names. This will make understanding our learning resources easier.

Dashboard

This is the place where all your projects are listed. By clicking on each project's dotted icon you can access options to duplicate, reveal in Finder and delete the project.

Library

The Library is the place where Animator lists your assets in a Tree View. It includes:

  • Components

  • Design files

  • Slices

  • Art-boards

  • SVGs

Stage

This is the place where you drag and drop your design slices to compose and animate them.

Timeline

With the timeline you can transform your slices in time and space to animate them. Parts of the timeline include:

  • Properties panel: Located at the left side of the timeline. This panel shows the editable properties for a given layer or component.

  • Layers: Listed inside the Properties Panel. Each of the slices you drag and drop onto the stage (action also known as "instantiation") becomes a layer in the timeline. You can reorganize them from top to bottom, you can lock them, add properties to them and more.

  • Properties: Nested inside and applied to each layer. They include options like "Opacity", "Scale", "Position", which are all editable and allow you to modify your layers/slices. You can add more Properties with the [Add] button.

  • Controls: Located at the bottom of the timeline. You can play, pause, jump to beginning/end and activate/deactivate playback.

  • Playhead or ticker: White vertical line with a round head. It indicates the current time of the animation. If you manually move or scrub it you will be able to play the animation frame by frame. Whenever you move the playhead and change a property's value, a new keyframe will be created at that exact moment in time.

  • Gauge: Placed at the top of the timeline. It marks the frames or milliseconds of your animation, which you can select using the toggle located next to it. If you click at any point in time in the lower part of the gauge, the playhead will jump to that spot. If you click on the upper part of the gauge, you will create a "Frame Action".

  • Keyframe: They mark different states of your slices in time and space.

  • Tweens: They are transitions implemented between keyframes to create the illusion of smooth motion.

States

States are buckets of data, or variables, which you can use in several ways in Animator. Read more here.

Main and components

Main, as its name suggests, is the main or primary stage of your project. Besides Main, you can create components (or "sub-components"), each with its own stage, states and timeline. These components can, at the same time, be instantiated in Main or in other components. 

Components will also appear listed in the Library, and if instantiated, they will appear in the timeline's Properties Panel as well.

You can toggle between Main and your components via the tab-bar placed above the stage. The active or selected component is marked in light-grey. You can also use the [+] button to create a new component.

Resources:

  • Component preview article

  • Intro to sub-components tutorial

Design mode vs Code mode

In Design mode you can view the Stage, which could be considered the visual representation of your project. In Code mode you can view Animator's code editor, which is the code-based representation of your project. You can edit your project with any of the two modes interchangeably! 

Preview mode

Like its name suggests, Preview Mode allows you to pause Edit mode and preview your animation to check how everything is looking before publishing your project and integrating it into your codebase.

Publish 

When you publish your project you can share it with others and get instructions on how to integrate it into your codebase.

data.title: Component preview
data.description: How to preview each component individually and all components together.
data.body:
When you create a component, you can preview its animation using its timeline [Play] button or its [Preview] button.

If you include this and other components in "Main", and you use Main's [Play] button, you will preview the animation created on Main's stage, but not each component’s animation. This allows you to focus on the animation at hand and to polish it with less distractions.

For example, you may have a component containing a rotating ball, and in Main you can include that component and make that rotating ball bounce on an imaginary floor. With Main's [Play] button you will see the ball bouncing (animation created in "Main") but not rotating (animation created in a component).

If you want to see how it all comes together, in both your components and in Main (e.g. the ball rotating and bouncing), you can use Main's [Preview] button.

data.title: Share page troubleshooting
data.description: My animation used to work but now it looks strange when I open it on the share page.
data.body:
This type of problem may be due to the version of Animator in which your project was created.

Try going back into your project and re-publishing it from the latest version of Animator.

data.title: Integrating Animator with a PHP app
data.description: Is it possible integrating Animator with an existing jQuery + PHP app?
data.body:
Absolutely! 

React/Vue support is actually via thin “adapters” that sit on top of our DOM (vanilla JS) adapter, which is all you need to render to DOM. 

We provide some code samples through the publish page (e.g. https://codepen.io/anon/pen/BrJoNK) to show you how you can simply include Animator via the CDN bundles we syndicate through the app. 

If you have a build pipeline to integrate, you can bring in your animation as regular NPM packages using the provided repositories in the React/Vue instructions—or, if you’re not using NPM, you can even use Haiku CLI to bring in your animation as Git submodules with haiku clone.

data.title: Adding transitions
data.description: How can I make my animation transition gradually from one value to the next?
data.body:
In the animation world, transitions are known as "tweens", which comes from the term "in-betweens". That is, a gradual transformation from one value (set on one keyframe) to the next value (set on another keyframe).

Creating a tween in Animator is very easy! You only need to right-click on the constant body (a.k.a the line) between two keyframes, and select a type of easing curve.

In the example above, we start with opacity=0 on frame 1, and end with opacity=1 on frame 20. We connected these two keyframes with a "cubic" ease-in curve.

Tip: Your animation will vary slightly depending on the type of easing curve you choose to use.

Note: Now Animator auto-tweens for you, using "Ease In Out Quad" as the default, which you can of course change, and even fine tune via the Bézier editor.

data.title: Feature requests, feedback and bugs
data.description: How can I report bugs or send feedback to the Haiku team?
data.body:
You can report bugs/issues, send feature requests and feedback to our team by writing in: 

  • The "Feedback" chat at the bottom-right of the app. 

  • In the #support or #feedback channels in our Slack Community

  • DM to me, @sasha.com, or @Tina via our Slack community

  • Email to support@haikuforteams.com 

Whatever's most convenient for you. We appreciate anything you can report!

data.title: Path or shape morphing
data.description: Does Animator support bézier curve editing?
data.body:
Yes! Shape morphing is a reality in Animator since version 4.0.0.

To trigger direct selection and expose the bézier handles on a shape you only need to double-click it.

In some cases, for example with an SVG rectangle, if you double-click on the <svg>  once, you will drill down to select the <rect> (the shape remains a <rect>). So, when you move the vertices, you will be sizing the <rect> directly. 

Double-clicking it again converts the <rect> to a <path>, and then you can move the vertices individually. 

Now, once you're editing the <path>, if you hold cmd  while you click on a vertex, the bézier handles will be exposed and you'll be able to edit the shape.

You can have even more control over the shape. If you hold alt  while moving the bézier control handles, you can achieve a "disconnected" (versus a "mirrored") behavior.

I want to know more!

We are constantly adding content to our Learn Page. Remember to visit it every once in a while to find useful tutorials on this and a lot of other topics!

data.title: GIF resolution
data.description: Can I choose from different resolutions to export my GIF?
data.body:
Supported GIF resolutions

  • Medium quality (15fps)

  • High quality (30fps + a more accurate palette)

How to

From the top menu bar, select "Project > Export".

Tip: You can even do this while you're offline!

More about GIF support

Please check out this article.


Note: If you need a higher resolution, try the Video export (60fps), which has the best fidelity.


Note: Subcomponents not animating in a GIF export is expected. The only way to get subcomponents to play is to render the component in a browser. The same goes for Lottie and Video.

data.title: Offline mode
data.description: Can I use Animator without an internet connection?
data.body:
Yes, you can!

What can I do while I'm offline?

You can:

  • Access the dashboard.

  • Create a new project, and work on it as you normally would.

  • Delete a project you created while offline that hasn't been published yet.

  • From the top menu (Project > export) you can export to video, medium and high quality GIF, and Lottie.

data.title: Lottie.json export
data.description: Can I export the lottie.JSON file without going through publish?
data.body:
How to

You can export the lottie.json file in two ways:

1- From the [Publish] modal, by clicking any option under "Mobile".

2- You can also use the top menu: Project > Export > Lottie

Tip: You can export your Lottie file through the top menu while you are offline!

Note: Subcomponents not animating in a Lottie export is expected. The only way to get subcomponents to play is to render the component in a browser. The same goes for Video and GIF.

data.title: Video export
data.description: Can I export my animation in .mp4 from Animator?
data.body:
How to

You can export videos in two ways:

1- From the [Publish] modal, you can export your animation in video format by clicking the [Video] option under "Other".

2- You can also use the top menu: Project > Export > Video

Tip: You can export your video through the top menu while you are offline!

Note: Subcomponents not animating in a Video export is expected. The only way to get subcomponents to play is to render the component in a browser. The same goes for Lottie and GIF.

data.title: Using Animator on several computers
data.description: How can I view my Animator files in more than one computer?
data.body:
To access your Animator files from more than one computer you only need to:

1- Log in with the same account credentials in both machines.
2- Make sure you publish all the changes you make to your projects in each machine.

When you first log-in on a new computer, you won't see the project's preview on the dashboard until you open each project, but all your work will be there!


Important note:

It is necessary to publish in order to get changes between the devices. If the user doesn't publish, the project never leaves his/her local machine.

One other possibility, if this isn't working, is that you have divergent copies of projects between your devices, e.g. where you worked on the same project on two machines in two different timelines, without first publishing/syncing changes. In that scenario, "bringing in" latest changes won't work, because histories are incompatible.  The best way to avoid this is to ensure that the latest version has been Published before editing on another machine.  A good way to fix this scenario if you're already in it would be to Duplicate one of the projects, and then treat the two histories as two separate projects entirely. Generally, duplicating projects (akin to MyFile001.psd and MyFile002.psd) is a useful way to manage concrete different versions & histories in Animator.

data.title: Disabling the "Crafted in Haiku Animator" context menu
data.description: Is there a way to disable the "Crafted in Haiku Animator" right click window? (vanilla HTML embed)
data.body:
Yes, you can disable the context menu by passing in contextMenu: 'disabled' to the mount options.

You need to set that option when you embed the code in your website, I created this CodePen as an example: https://codepen.io/roperzh/pen/BvNppR 

You can also see the documentation about this topic here: https://docs.haikuforteams.com/embedding-and-using-haiku/haiku-core-api.html#embedapi

data.title: Motion blur
data.description: Can Animator do motion blurs?
data.body:
No we don’t have this effect available yet. 

What you could try is:

  1. Make another copy of the element you want to blur while in motion. Apply a gaussian blur to it from Sketch. 

  2. Apply the same position and motion tweens to both blurred and non-blurred elements. 

  3. Set the blurred element’s opacity to 0. Then during the motion segment, reduce the opacity of the non-blurred element to 0 and while setting the blurred element to 1. 

https://share.haiku.ai/u/Tina/MotionBlur

Bonus idea: stretch the element’s scale during the motion portion as well for an exaggerated effect.

data.title: Recover work using Git
data.description: I think I lost some work. Can I recover it?
data.body:
Every project folder is backed by git, so you’ll be able to restore a previous commit on your machine. We don't yet offer a UI for reverting to previous versions, so you'll need to do this by the command line. 

First you need to click Developer -> Open in Terminal to open a new terminal session at your project folder path.

Then you can step back one revision by typing:
git reset —hard HEAD~1 

After stepping back one revision, try opening the project again in Animator. If it's not the version you want, try again a few more times. You can also step back multiple revisions at once by changing the number after HEAD , e.g. HEAD~5  would take you back 5 revisions.

Another option would be to (carefully) do git reset --hard <sha1 of the last known good commit>, after first using git diff to figure out where things went wrong.

data.title: Error when using your animation in a project
data.description: 404: Failed to load resource
data.body:
This isn’t really an error—when you embed an animation on the web, by default it has a right-click context menu that looks like this: 

To populate the menu option, Haiku Core pings our server to see if the project was set to be “public” when it was published. The 404 just means it’s not public—and as a result, the right-click menu won’t show an option to “Fork this component” or “View on Haiku Community”.

If you want to disable the right-click menu in your app, you can set up your animation using the option {contextMenu: 'disabled'}.

Here’s an example: https://codepen.io/anon/pen/PRpQVB
